Column: 2343

          Head K - Ministry of Education (cont.) -

 

     Resumption of Debate on Question [17th March, 2004],

 

     "That the total sum to be allocated for Head K of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Wang Kai Yuen].

 

      Question again proposed.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Acting Minister for Education (Mr Hawazi Daipi): Sir, I will continue with my reply to Mdm Halimah in Malay.

     (In Malay):  Sir, yesterday, I explained to Mdm Halimah that the Ministry of Education has carried out a number of measures to ensure that students who are taught the standardised pronunciation be given the appropriate guidance.  And I have also explained why it is important for the small Malay community to have a similar policy on standardisation and pronunciation of the Malay language for the society as well as schools.  I would like to elaborate on my answer.

     I have said that for the small Malay community in Singapore, it is better for us to have a standardised language policy that is similar for schools and the general public that could guide on the use of the Malay language headed by the Malay Language Council of Singapore. If MOE drops the use of standardised pronunciation in schools, there will be no uniformity between the spoken language used in schools and in public at formal occasions.  This will not be in line with the objective of the Malay Language Council of Singapore which is supported by the Ministry of Education.  The aim of the MLCS in implementing the standardised pronunciation is for Singapore to share its identity in its cultural and language context with the neighbouring

Column: 2344

countries in the region that are using the Malay language.

     The implementation of the standardised pronunciation is not to replace the existing Johore-Riau pronunciation.  Historically, due to Singapore's proximity to Johore and Riau, the Malays in Singapore have been using the Johore-Riau pronunciation in their formal and informal communication.  Although the bazaar-form of Malay Johore-Riau pronunciation is still being used widely in everyday interaction and in informal situation, the use of standardised pronunciation is encouraged in formal occasions, such as in education, teaching and learning in classrooms, in speeches, at seminars, forums, formal meetings, interviews, competitions such as debates, and so on.

    One major difference between Singapore and its neighbouring countries in the use of standardised pronunciation is the existence of a number of dialects in these countries.  In Indonesia, for instance, there are more than 250 dialects which at certain levels can result in linguistic interference which impedes a student from acquiring the standardised pronunciation needed.  Standardised pronunciation in Indonesia is much influenced by dialects and the Javanese vocabulary.  Due to this, we did not choose Indonesia as our guide, although Indonesia has been using its form of standardised pronunciation since 1928.

     As for Brunei Darussalam, standardised pronunciation has been used within their society which applies the Brunei dialect and vocabulary.  However, their students are able to speak in sebutan baku effectively in formal occasions, such as in the Titian Minda debate which involves Singapore and Brunei pre-university students. 

     In the case of Malaysia, sebutan baku was implemented since 1988.  According

Column: 2345

to the Education Department of Malaysia, sebutan baku is still being used in Malaysian schools.  However, its usage has been confined to the teaching and learning of Malay language.

     Like the other communities in Singapore, there are now more Malay families who speak English at home.  The percentage has increased from 6.1% of households in 1990 to 7.9% in the year 2000.  This trend is expected to grow in the future.  The use of sebutan baku  that has a consistent association between script and sound will facilitate the learning of the language for our students who are less exposed to the Malay language at home, including non-Malays who offer Malay language in schools.

     So it is clear that sebutan baku  is more systematic and logical than the Johore-Riau pronunciation.  It is also easier for the students to learn the Malay language using sebutan baku.  The Ministry will continue to teach in and encourage the use of sebutan baku in schools.

     Education Standards

 

     Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio):   Sir, the Ministry plans to increase the intake of polytechnic and university students.  Such expansion allows opportunities in tertiary education for more of our students.  This is a good thing.  However, such expansion can affect the quality of education and educational standards.  This can occur in many areas, for example, content and instruction delivery, teachers' training and testing. 

 

     Experience in the UK and elsewhere saw inflation of grades and the lowering of the quality of graduates.  May I therefore ask the Minister if he has such concerns and, if so, what does the Ministry plan to do in order to avoid or minimise these negative aspects of expansion in student intakes?

Column: 2346

     School Session

 

     Dr Ong Seh Hong (Aljunied):   Sir, Singapore has an excellent education system that is looked upon with envy.  However, we can still improve further on our education system.  I understand that all the secondary schools are now single sessions.  I am keen to know what is the progress of single session for primary schools.  I would be grateful if the Minister could give us an update.  And I would like to know also whether the Ministry intends to make all primary school classes single session.

   

     Sir, single session for primary schools has many spinoffs.  One of them is that we can actually change the starting hour to later than it is now.  Because of the two sessions that are currently still going on in many schools, primary schools here start at a very unhealthy hour of 7.30 am.  I understand that some schools even start their assemblies at 7.15 am.  On a normal school day, tens of thousands of students wake up before 6.00 am to make it to school.  I am sure they do not really enjoy this type of morning routine.  For many a family, actually the whole family wakes up before 6.00 am and then they have to rush to prepare the kids for school.  This routine repeats itself in the evening.  Thereafter, the parents are expected to have the energy and the time to spend with their children and, maybe, even make more babies for Singapore!  I think we can do something about it. 

 

     Therefore, I urge the Ministry to change the starting hour of our school sessions, maybe to 8.30 am.  This is surely doable, with more schools becoming single session.  I know of a Singaporean, Mr Rajindran Ramasamy, who is a professional working with Reuters in London.  He will strongly vouch for schools which start their session late.  He lives with his wife and three children.  The later starting hour in the school in

Column: 2347

London has allowed him to spend quality time with his children in the morning, have sufficient time to send them to school without having to rush and then get to work.  Similarly, the kids have time to recover from a day full of activities and spend quality time with their families.  This is a pro-family practice that we can adopt easily while not affecting the quality of education received by our children. 

 

     May I take my next cut, Sir?

 

          The Chairman:  Yes.

     Class Size

 

     Dr Ong Seh Hong:  Sir, the Minister mentioned to us in the last Budget that his Ministry was introducing smaller class size for Primary 1 and Primary 2 cohorts.  I would like to ask the Minister for an update on this policy decision, and also how prepared we are for this.  It is a dilemma when we ask for a smaller class size.  But with a smaller teacher-to-student ratio, actually we require more teachers to do a good job.  This should not compromise on the quality of the teachers while reducing the class size.  So I would like the Minister to give us an update on the progress of the recruitment of teachers and whether he could assure us that standards will not be compromised.  With all the benefits of smaller class sizes, will the Ministry also be considering extending this smaller teacher-to-student ratio to higher primary as well as secondary schools?

 

     Mr S Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, from the time I came into this Chamber, I have been advocating smaller class sizes, and the Ministry's response has been the limited resources, especially in terms of quality teachers.  Then I was suggesting incremental steps, and was very heartened last year when the

Column: 2348

announcement was made to introduce smaller class sizes, at least at the P1 and P2 levels.  But the catch was that it is going to be left to individual schools to decide, based on their own resource constraints.  In other words, they would have to adjust their scheduling, maybe have P1 and P2 in the afternoon session, and then P3 to P6 in the morning, and have no change therefore in the overall resource allocation but juggling it within what they already have.

 

     I have a few questions that I would like the Minister to respond to.  The first is: how many schools have actually adopted smaller class sizes for P1 and P2?  Although this has been made available as a policy statement, I would like to know what is the experience on the ground.  The reason I ask this in particular is because, for the more popular primary schools, there is the tension that, without additional resources, they cannot maintain their enrolment and still have smaller class sizes.  There is a tradeoff between the two.  So, if they adopt smaller class sizes, they may end up actually denying their old boys, old girls, alumni school community, additional places at P1 for registration purposes. 

 

     I would like to know what is the adoption rate and what the feedback has been, in terms of any problems and pedadogic-related issues, and whether the Ministry has specific plans to enhance the resources available so that the adoption of these smaller class sizes, at least at the initial stage at P1 and P2 levels, can be more widespread.

     Teachers

 

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah):  Sir, these should be exciting times for teachers, as many changes have been made to the education system which should give teachers more flexibility in their teaching methodologies, assessment models and, even some say, in student

Column: 2349

intake.  A recent survey found that new graduate teachers from NIE maintain their poll position as top earners among 4,000 graduates from NTU, beating even the engineering, accountancy and business graduates.  The Ministry's recent announcement to allow teachers to go on attachment with businesses, community organisations and even overseas schools shows MOE's commitment to help teachers gain valuable experience outside the classroom which they can share with their students. 

 

     While the intention of this scheme is commendable, one wonders how many teachers can really benefit from this scheme, as feedback is that teacher workload remains heavy.  Teachers with children, for instance, may not be willing to give up spending whatever time they have during the holidays with their children to go on industrial attachment. 

 

     Sir, teaching used to be synonymous with a family-friendly career, as teachers used to work half a day and can spend the rest of the day with their family.  However, over the years, in our quest for high quality education, which is a good thing by itself, teacher workload appears to have increased inordinately.  I understand that a secondary school teacher, besides teaching from 7.30 am to 2.00 pm, carries a host of other duties, such as CCA, student contact time, counselling sessions, remedial classes, committee meetings, marking, setting tests and examinations, and other administrative work after school.  Further, there are also the compulsory training hours that teachers have to clock.  Hence, teachers nowadays work very long hours, shouldering both teaching as well as other loads.

 

 

11.15 am

 

     Anecdotal evidence suggests that a significant number of teachers are single.  With such a heavy workload, one

Column: 2350

wonders how they can find time to socialise and find their soulmates.  The many recent changes implemented in the education system will no doubt add to this workload.  According to Mrs Carmee Lim, Executive Director of the Academy of Principals, teachers are so hard-pressed for time, they have no time to even read the newspapers.  They are so caught up in their own little box, any opportunity to help them get out of this state is good.  I would, therefore, like to urge the Ministry to undertake a thorough review of teacher workload to determine if the teachers can cope, and also if their workload can be reduced by devolving as much non-teaching duties as possible, such as CCA, counselling responsibilities, etc, from the teachers.  This is to ensure that good teachers are retained and their quality of teaching does not suffer from stress due to work overload.

     Dr Tan Boon Wan: Sir, I join Dr Amy Khor to ask the Ministry to take a look at what the teachers are doing in school.  Stress the teachers face - a topic that has been raised many times over, and I am sure the Ministry has taken serious actions on it.  But it appears to be a problem that refuses to quietly lie down and die.  It continues to cause anguish.  Some teachers said that they and their colleagues continue to see their doctors for problems related to stress.  I would, therefore, like to request the Minister for an update on the situation and what further steps will be taken to reduce the problem and help teachers cope with stress.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, teaching has changed so much over the last 30 years since Singapore embarked on its education strategy.  In the past, our focus was simply on literacy and employment.  Teaching in schools was at the basic level, so that our people are able to read, write well and find a good job.  It is a lot different now, especially with the slew of further changes announced

Column: 2351

yesterday.  While the focus still remains on literacy and employment continues to be important, there are also so many other things that have become equally critical, eg, the nurturing of creativity, the importance of National Education, the focus on multi-disciplinary learning, the drive for arts and sports, the dynamics of entrepreneurism, and the need for diversified programmes.  Such are the demands of this global environment in which Singapore participates. 

 

     What do all these changes translate into where teachers are concerned?  It means that we need to have a very different batch of teachers than those of earlier years.  Our teachers are now expected to have a global perspective while retaining a local flavour.  Our teachers not only teach the students but, increasingly, have to deal with parents as customers of the school.  Our teachers must complete the syllabus on time and on budget as set by the Ministry, and also imbue in the ear experiential learning and creative delivery.  Our teachers must build relationships with those that they teach and also build passion for the school in which they teach in.  All these sound extremely exciting, but they add on to the stress and burden of our teachers, which could affect the attractiveness of this very noble profession.  I understand that some have difficulties catching up with the changes that are taking place. 

 

     I would like to ask the Minister how are we developing our teachers for this exciting and yet exhausting future.  In what ways has NIE improved its basic orientation training programme, the one-year beginner teacher course, to prepare our teachers?  How has the programme included the new important aspects of a teacher's life over and above just teaching well in class?  Has the school helped in the continuous development of our teachers after they have been posted to

Column: 2352

the school?  How are our teachers learning to do new things like customer relationships? 

 

     Sir, I also understand that a new scheme called Enhanced Performance Management System was introduced in 2003 to assess teachers.  Can the Minister enlighten the House as to how teachers are assessed and evaluated for greater effectiveness in their skills in relating to students and parents?  How will this scheme also award teachers for embracing a more socially-inclined lifestyle that will help to promote our procreation policy?

     Quality Teaching Force

 

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, teachers play a critical role in our education system, so the MOE strives to ensure that our teachers not only have the textbook knowledge to teach students a particular subject but have actual life experience to make their teaching much more relevant to real life needs.  The new MOE scheme would allow teachers to go outside the classroom and into the business sector, community organisations and even schools overseas to gain experience outside the classrooms, so that they can return with skills to share.  However, the feedback that I have received is that while there is a policy in terms of implementation, there is not much progress, as principals, who will ultimately have to decide whether or not to release a teacher, are concerned with completing the syllabus in time and fear disruption to the classes. 

 

     Sir, we have 26,000 teachers and this scheme was announced last year.  My question to the Minister is: how many percent of these 26,000 teachers have indeed gone on corporate attachments?  How does the Ministry propose to address the concerns of principals who have genuine issues and concerns about how the scheme would affect teaching

Column: 2353

schedules in the schools?  Can the MOE make the scheme really meaningful in terms of providing additional support to schools if teachers have to be taken out from their lessons, so that there will be minimal disruption to the classes?

     Professional Ethics of Teachers

 

     Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member):  Sir, in line with my parliamentary colleagues' desire to help the teaching profession, I would like to turn to the question of professional standards of our teachers. 

 

     Lately, there have been a few court cases of teachers who had sexual liaisons with their students.  Apart from criminal sanctions against errant teachers, what is the Ministry doing to instill a professional and ethical code of conduct amongst its education officers and to impose professional sanctions, eg, suspension from practising their vocation for a period of time or even be barred from teaching altogether?  We find that in many other established professions, there are such sanctions.   I would be glad if the Ministry could explain what are its policies and procedures in this regard.

     Co-curricular Activities

 

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan:  Sir, I am pleased that the Ministry is putting more emphasis on a well-rounded education which goes beyond academic performance.  It has begun none too soon to put more weight on other non-academic areas, such as CCA in sports.  Schools have been given awards for their sporting achievements.  However, only selected students and not all who wish to join are able to participate in a sports CCA.  This could be for a variety of reasons, including inadequate facilities, and perhaps the schools' desire to excel in their chosen sports, so that only the exceptional students with the highest

Column: 2354

chance of excelling are allowed to participate.

 

     Sir, I would like to urge the Ministry to encourage schools to work together with grassroots organisations and parents to allow more students to participate in at least one sport on a regular basis.  For instance, little leagues for football, netball, basketball, etc, could be formed, and parents and grassroots organisations could be roped in to help get these sports going for every child who wishes to participate, regardless of his or her aptitude.  Sports inculcate in our students teamwork, mental strength, physical toughness, endurance and leadership skills, and help to develop our children into well-balanced healthy individuals.  It would also help to reduce many children's tendency to become couch potatoes, sitting in front of the TV or computer for hours.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Sir, during the cut on Sports For All, which you, for overrun of time, cut me short, I would now like to highlight a story of how Norway was successful in the World Cup.  The article in the Straits Times in February 2004, headlined "World Cup: How Norway did it", the President of the Norwegian Football Association was reported to have said:  "We have to get the basics right first to give the Norwegian children opportunities to play football.  The NFF created clubs in every neighbourhood for children to join from the age of six."  The emphasis is on the opportunity to play. 

 

     I will again quote the Straits Times' article on the interview with the Minister himself, his background and the importance of play and teamwork that had shaped him: "I think a lot of what I am was actually shaped in my school days.  I spent my time playing sports almost every day of the year, sometimes two sports in a day, and often until it was too dark to see the ball.  You learn to take

Column: 2355

knocks, to go in for the tackle, to live with your scars.  You rely on your team mates.  You lead, you win and lose as a team.  There was great camaraderie."  His thoughts on 2nd September 2003 at the opening of the CCA conference were:  "CCA has been changed from ECA in 1991 to give emphasis that co-curricular activities are an integral part of education, not an add-on or option.  If CCA has been important in the past, it will be more important in the future.  This is because some of the key traits that our young need to succeed in a more complex and frequently changing future will be cultivated most effectively by engaging them in CCA, in teams, as well as in individual pursuits." 

 

     From these quotes, clearly, CCA is important and it is an integral part of our education system.  May I then ask the Minister: if CCA is important and should be emphasised in our schools, why do our principals keep telling the students and parents that there are insufficient resources for the children to take part in CCA?  How many schools allow their students to participate in CCA without any selection process, and why is there a need for a selection process just for play or learn to play?  Is the Ministry not putting in enough resources on the ground?  And most of the students are directed to be librarians, with least of the resources needed?  The guidelines and awards given to schools for CCA excellence are in contradiction to the policies of CCA for mass participation and allowing as many children the joy of learning as a team in CCA and sports.  Will the Ministry review the guidelines and policies of the award of CCA excellence in schools?

     Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, it has come to my knowledge that some schools have removed certain extra-curricular activities (CCAs) because they feel that with the current talent in the

Column: 2356

school, winning in competitions may not be possible.  If indeed this is true, I am appalled at the message that we are sending the children, ie, "If you cannot excel in sports and be victorious, then let us forget about it."  Is that the correct attitude to adopt?  Is that a good example to set? 

 

     Under the prevailing social climate, let me assure you that we will not regret imbuing our children with the sporting ethos of fair play and equality under the laws of the game, rather than simply preparing them to survive and prosper in the law of the jungle conditions which currently prevails.  In addition to that, some schools actually view sports through coloured lenses by associating some types of sports with certain character traits, for example, dropping football or soccer as a choice, with the reason that it may bring negative influence.  This is very sad and should not be happening in our schools.  I must declare my interest at this juncture as the Vice-Chairman of the Football Association of Singapore, as I know that several schools have scrapped soccer in their CCAs for one reason or another.  Soccer is one of the few sports that has a very wide following and is a very good vehicle for bonding, promoting team spirit and for character development. 

 

     Sir, the school is one place where the children can acquire not only knowledge but also the opportunity to develop their potential to the fullest, and to mould their individual character and know their strengths and weaknesses.  Apart from classroom lessons, interest groups, clubs, uniformed groups, the sports field and the other places like the gymnasium, the tennis, badminton or squash courts as well as the swimming pools are places where they also learn and develop their character.  This is a very important part of education.  We must have both because, at the end of the school years, we want to give our children a holistic education. 

Column: 2357

Nevertheless, there must be a balance in CCA and classroom work.  Parents are also worried that some schools put so much emphasis on CCAs that their children hardly have time for their studies.  In this respect, may I ask the Minister what are the guidelines for schools on CCAs?  What is the balance recommended between studies and CCA hours?  Do principals alone decide what sports are to be included or excluded from CCAs?  How does MOE monitor the CCA curriculum at the schools?  Can MOE assist in making some of the sports facilities more accessible to the community so that more opportunities are open to the young living near the schools?

 

11.30 am

     Hobbies and Interests

 

     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member):  Sir, I am pleased that the Ministry is finally going to improve the school ranking scheme to take into account character building and CCAs.  However, the current scheme of activities open to school children does fall into the predictable list, to name a few, eg, football, rugby, hockey, softball, or the co-curricular activities such as drama, public speaking, uniformed units, librarianship, IT clubs.  If we wish to nurture the varied interests of our children,

be it in the areas of stamp collecting, movie discussion groups, book clubs, saving the endangered species of animal groups, etc, we also need to create the environment around them. Children do care about the many things that happen around them and in the world, but we, as parents and teachers, sometimes give them a prescribed list of activities, be they ballet, piano or art classes, thus robbing them sometimes of their own interests. I feel that such interests can be further nurtured, harnessed, honed or dropped, if the child's interest wanes. We do not need to stay with an activity in a predictable

     The Acting Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam): Streaming in Schools

 

     Sir, several Members have spoken on the subject of streaming in primary and secondary schools. Let me first address the more general observations that Members have made before informing the House of specific refinements that MOE will be making in primary school streaming and in the Normal course in secondary schools.

 

     Streaming has done us well, and it remains an educationally sound policy.  It recognises that different students have different abilities, different types of intelligence and different ways of learning.  It seeks to provide them with the curriculum and teaching methods that help them develop and sustain an interest in their studies.  It helps every student to go as far as he can. 

 

     Some Members - Dr Lily Neo, Mdm Cynthia Phua and some others - have said that streaming results in stress and a loss of confidence.  It is not an irrelevant concern.  I do not doubt that there is some loss of confidence when a student is differentiated from his peers and advised to take a less challenging or more extended course of study.  No one likes being told that.  It is a human reaction.  But the issue is less simple than that.  Is the student more stressed by being channelled into an academically slower course or by staying on in a course that he is unable to cope with, taking exercises home that he is unable to complete, having questions asked in class that he is unable to answer and, finally, being unable to pass his examinations?  I think we know the answer.

 

Column: 2361

     The fact of the matter is that confidence or self-esteem is much more a question of how well students do and how far they eventually go, than on whether they get to do the same thing as everyone else at the same time.  Outcomes matter.  And we are determined to help every student achieve the best outcomes he can - in school, when he leaves school and goes on to a post-secondary institution, or when he joins a workplace and has to count on his skills to earn a living.  That  is our best chance of giving every Singaporean a confident start in life. 

 

     MOE is fully aware that many other systems do not stream students or stream them later than we do.  It comes at great cost, ie, high drop-out rates, sometimes disguised by compulsory education up to the junior secondary years.  And the academically faster students being held back, unchallenged and bored with their studies.  Dr Tan Boon Wan just mentioned the issue of standards having fallen in British universities as a result of a rapid expansion.  It is not just because of the rapid expansion in the university intake.  It is also because of many years of experimentation with egalitarian policies in schools, leading to a lowering of standards so that as many students as possible can pass and obtain the same qualification.  So much so that universities are now requiring first-year students to take remedial classes, including students who have "A" grades in the UK 'A' levels.

 

     The British recently released a report by Mike Tomlinson, former Chief Inspector of Schools, which proposes an overhaul of the British GCSE and 'A' level systems.  As he put it, too many young people leave learning or fail to progress.  And too many are left unchallenged and constrained by the curriculum they are offered. It is not a very different picture, as Members would know, from what we had in Singapore before streaming was introduced.

 

Column: 2362

     So, let us stick to a system that is focused on achieving strong outcomes for all.  The most unambiguous result of streaming is that we have helped our weaker students go much further.  We are doing our EM3 students well. About 90% of primary 6 EM3 students proceed to a secondary education.  70% of them complete a secondary education.  More than 50% of each EM3 cohort proceeds on to a post-secondary education at the ITE.  I know of no other system which has had as much success in ensuring that students at the weakest end of the academic spectrum stay on in education, go on to a post-secondary institution and acquire real skills which they take into the workforce.

 

     As several Members have asked - Dr Wang, Dr Lily Neo, Mr Chiam See Tong, Mr Low Thia Khiang and Dr Ong Seh Ong - are we streaming too early in primary schools?  I ask principals and teachers that from time to time.  They are kind-hearted souls by nature, like most MPs.  They do not like to conclude that the student is unable to cope with his studies and needs a different course. So I can tell the House that I believe teachers when they tell me that we would be doing most of our EM3 students a disservice if we keep them in the regular curriculum in Primary 5 and Primary 6.  These are students who lag significantly behind the rest of the cohort, despite remedial teaching. 

 

     If each of us thinks back to our own primary school days, we would have known pupils who were with us who were very weak in class.  In our time, there was no streaming.  My own best friend in my early primary years repeated a year twice.  He finally dropped out before reaching the PSLE.  We did not have a slower course of study then, so those who could not understand their lessons and tests would repeat a year and, if they still could not cope, they dropped out.  It was a bad solution to the

Column: 2363

problem then, and will be a bad solution now.

 

     I should add that the EM3 cohort is not a large group. 12% of students are recommended by the schools to enter EM3 after Primary 4. Because many of their parents choose to put them in EM2, the final number in EM3 is 7%.

 

     The students are by and large happy in EM3.  They feel they are able to follow their studies, and have something to show.  But parents often do not like the fact that the school has recommended their child to be in EM3, and that is the bigger part of the problem to be overcome.  However, parents do come round when they see how their child benefits.  I asked for feedback from parents of EM3 students.  A sampling may give Members a sense of what EM3 really does.  One parent said he was disappointed when he was told that his daughter had to go to EM3.  He said he "lost face".  But he recognised that his daughter was weak, and said he could tell that she was happier, because the work was simpler and she was coping well.  A second parent said all his relatives had been advising him to put his son in EM2 instead of accepting the school's recommendation.  But now that the boy is struggling to pass his EM3 subjects, he feels that his son is much better off in the stream.  A third parent said that although her daughter had managed to clear her Primary 5 examinations in EM2 and could remain in EM2, she had opted for her child to go to EM3, because the child was too stressed with having to cope with EM2 subjects.  In EM3 this year, she is happier. She has done very well in her Continual Assessment 1 (CA1), and has gained confidence.  These are not unique accounts, and they are telling accounts.

 

     What our schools try to do is to encourage intermingling of students from

Column: 2364

different streams, so that they build friendships outside classrooms.   CCAs provide avenues for this.  Students in the same CCA support each other in common endeavours, they learn to work with each other and appreciate each other's strengths in different areas.  This is something our schools will continue to encourage.  And they will seek out more opportunities for interaction between students in different streams, by looking into different ways of organising school activities or PE, as Mr Inderjit Singh suggested yesterday.

 

     We will also ensure that the system is flexible enough, so that students can go as far as they can in their specific areas of strength.  Where a student shows good progress overall and is able to transfer to a faster stream, we will let him do so.  We do so each year, especially after Secondary 1.  Where a student is capable of taking one or two subjects at a higher level, we will let him do so.  This applies to EM3 students as well as our Normal (Academic) and Normal (Technical) students, which I will elaborate on briefly in a short while.

 

     At the primary level, as part of the easing of rules governing Mother Tongue learning, MOE had announced earlier this year that we will allow EM3 students to offer MTL, instead of Basic Mother Tongue, which is the norm for EM3 students, if they obtain Band 2 or better in the subject in their Primary 4 examinations.  We will consider whether there are educational merits to extending this to any other subject, for example, to let an EM3 student take Mathematics at the EM2 level, if he has strength in the subject.  This is what was suggested by Mr Inderjit Singh and a couple of other MPs. It would complicate timetabling arrangements, but we will be quite open to letting any school pilot this, if it sees EM3 students with these abilities and is able to make practical arrangements.

Merging EM1 and EM2

 

     Dr Khor and Mr Gan Kim Yong suggested mixing EM1 and EM2 classes, since EM1 students only offer one subject, HMTL, that is different.  MOE has been reviewing this, following the recent easing of requirements for students to take HMTL.  There is an overlap in abilities of students taking EM1 and EM2.  20% of our Primary 5 students are in EM1.  But almost half of the 20% are students who were first recommended by schools to take EM2, but whose parents chose EM1.

With the enhanced flexibility for students to take Higher Mother Tongue, there will now be an increasing overlap in abilities between EM1 and EM2 students. 

 

     MOE has, therefore, decided to remove the distinction between EM1 and EM2 in primary schools.  Schools will decide on how to band their pupils, in ways that add the most educational value. They will be given the flexibility to organise the students in this broader programme according to their own criteria.  I expect many schools may retain the present system of organising students according to their overall Primary 4 results. Some schools may decide to band students according to their language strengths - English Language and Mother Tongue respectively - for special attention. The arrangements will vary depending on the type of students in a school and how widely their abilities vary. How the students should be banded should be best left to the schools. 

 

     We are able to combine EM1 and EM2 because they follow essentially the same course of study, leading to the PSLE, within the same span of time.  There will be no change at the primary level to the Gifted Education Programme, which provides a different curriculum and teaching methods for exceptionally bright

Column: 2366

students  -  an enriched curriculum.  EM3 will also remain a distinct course, focusing on foundational knowledge, for all the reasons I mentioned earlier.  Our weakest students benefit from being taught separately, using a different curriculum, different classroom management techniques and different teaching approach.

 

Flexibility in Primary 4 Examinations

 

     We have also reviewed the current arrangements for the Primary 4 examinations, which currently serve as a streaming examination. With the merging of EM1 and EM2, we will give schools greater discretion in how they assess their pupils in P4.

 

     Schools currently recommend a student's stream in Primary 5 based on a student's semestral assessments and an end-of-year examination at Primary 4.  Schools select questions from a national item bank that is maintained by MOE, but they are responsible for marking and grading their own students. It is, in essence, already a school-based examination, but operating within a common MOE framework.

 

     With the removal of the distinction between the EM1 and EM2 streams, we will give schools the flexibility to use their own assessments of students' performance in the course of semestral examinations, the end-of-year examinations or other assessments, to identify students who are capable of studying Higher Mother Tongue in Primary 5.  They would do likewise in identifying students who should be recommended to take the EM3 course. The Primary 4 examinations would therefore be like any other end-of-year school examinations at any other level.

 

      Schools can develop their own assessment items, or choose to select questions from the national item bank that MOE will maintain.  They can also

schedule their examinations later in the year, instead of in October currently, along with the school-based examinations for other levels. 

    

     Schools will be given the flexibility to develop their own end-of-year Primary 4 examinations from this year.  MOE will work with primary schools to ensure smooth implementation of these changes.

 

Normal Course 

 

     At the secondary level, we are also introducing greater flexibility across courses. As announced in 2002, from this year, Normal (Academic) students have been allowed to offer one or two 'O' level subjects at Secondary 4.   Mdm Halimah asked about the progress of this initiative.  For a start, Mother Tongue Language and Mathematics have been offered, as Normal (Academic) students are more likely to have done well in these subjects.  Initial estimates from schools indicate that over 2,000 Normal (Academic) students have been assessed by the schools to have the ability and commitment to offer one or two 'O' levels, and are currently preparing to take the 'O' levels in Seccondary 4 this year.  This is about 15% of the Secondary 4 Normal (Academic) cohort, not a small number.

 

     Ms Braema had suggested yesterday a 3-year  Normal (Academic) course.  The Normal (Academic) course currently leads up to the 'N' level examinations at the end of four years. Students who are able to take the 'O' levels then spend an additional year, a total of five years. This '4+1' system has worked well.  25% of our Normal (Academic) students do not progress to Secondary 5.  The 4-year course provides them a sound foundation for post-secondary education. Further, even amongst the 75% of Secondary 4N students who do progress to Secondary 5, a significant proportion needs the full

four years initially to cover the Normal curriculum. They will not be well served by a shorter Normal (Academic) course.  Many of those who make it to Secondary 5, in fact, find the 'O' levels to be a major challenge, and do not do well enough in their 'O' levels to go on to pre-university or polytechnic. They are well-served by having gone through a 4-year  Normal (Academic) course, which allows them to graduate with a useful 'N' level certificate that recognises what they achieved. 

 

     Dr Khor spoke about enhancing the Normal (Technical) course yesterday.   MOE has been reviewing the Normal (Technical) course, which is now in its 11th year.    It has worked well. The core subjects in the Normal (Technical) curriculum, comprising English, Basic Mother Tongue, Mathematics and CPA, provide a broad-based foundation that prepares students well for both technical and service-oriented courses at the post-secondary level.  We are studying how to build on these fundamentals, and further customise the Normal (Technical) curriculum to meet the needs of students with a practical intelligence.   This will require a reorientation of the syllabuses and teaching methods to focus more on practice-oriented learning. We are also studying how to introduce alternative assessment modes, such as individual and team coursework, instead of pen-and-paper tests alone.

 

     This is a major curriculum review, and we will not rush to implement the changes to the Normal (Technical) syllabus. MOE will announce details of this review later.

 

     We will, however, introduce some flexibility in the Normal (Technical) course to allow students to offer one or two Normal (Academic) subjects, if they have the ability to do so.  This is similar to Normal (Academic) students being allowed to take one or two 'O' level subjects, similar to the Express classes,

Primary Education

 

     Dr Ong Seh Hong and Mr Iswaran asked for an update on two major initiatives that we announced last year, in fact, at the Committee of Supply debate,  at the primary school level - smaller class sizes at Primary 1 and Primary 2, and enabling Primary 3 to Primary 6 pupils to study in a single session environment.  We have enough teachers to implement the smaller class sizes at P1 and P2, starting with the P1 cohort in 2005.  All schools will be given additional teacher resources to support the smaller class initiative.  In parallel, MOE is promoting more varied teaching methodologies to improve the learning experiences of Primary 1 and Primary 2 pupils and take the most advantage of smaller classes.

 

     Twenty-four schools are currently involved in a project we call GAIN (Grade-Appropriate Instruction and Assessment), a project to help schools think through how they can strengthen pupils' learning in their foundation years.  The schools are identifying localised issues, classroom issues, that need to be tackled and are coming up with strategies to better support early learning, particularly in the context of smaller classes that are going to come on stream. 

 

     Progress is also being made in implementing single session for Primary 3 to Primary 6, and we expect full roll-out within 10 years.   Dr Ong Seh Hong had spoken of the possible benefits of single session and asked if we could  implement it faster.  With partial single session and

Column: 2370

smaller P1 and P2 classes, schools will have a smaller capacity. Schools that currently operate close to full capacity will therefore have to adjust their Primary 1 intakes, to gradually bring their total enrolment down to single session levels.  Where physical capacity and the demand for school places allow, schools will transit to partial single session as soon as possible.  The Ministry estimates that more than 100 schools -  in other words 60% of primary schools - can implement partial single session by year 2007. There are 12 Government-aided schools which are already operating full single session, from Primary 1 to Primary 6.

     

     Members also raised broader questions of class size.  Dr Ong had asked if we could extend small class sizes across the board.  Ideally, we should have small classes across the board, every one of which taught by good teachers.  But there is a real trade-off between quality and quantity of teachers when we try to implement smaller class sizes across the entire system.  We can double the size of the teaching force so as to halve class sizes, but we can only do so by lowering the standards we require of our teachers. The choice is between, quite simply, having 40 students taught by a good teacher, and two classes of 20, one of which will be taught by a teacher who may not be fit to teach by today's standards.

 

     Our approach is to recruit as many teachers as we can who meet our standards.  We have not limited the numbers that we can recruit.  Through EduPac, we have made a career in teaching more attractive and rewarding.  We have been able to build up the size of our teaching force gradually over the last five years, from 23,500 in 1999 to 26,500 in 2003.  However, it is unlikely that we can have a dramatic increase in the size of our teaching force without a significant lowering of quality.  This will be particularly the case with the recovery

Column: 2371

in the economy and the availability of more options for jobs for graduates from our universities in future.

 

     Given these constraints, our position on deploying our teacher resources is to do so where the additional teachers can contribute most towards the learning of students.  This is why we have focused our teacher resources to reduce class sizes at P1 and P2 in the first instance. That is where most research shows there is greatest benefit in having smaller classes.  Another good example is the Learning Support Programme (LSP) where Primary 1 and 2 pupils with difficulties in basic literacy skills are taught in small group sizes of 8-12 pupils.  It is a very teacher-intensive programme but we think it is necessary and it pays off.   Using teacher resources in this targeted fashion is more effective than trying to reduce class sizes across the board. 

 

     Dr Tan Boon Wan and Dr Amy Khor expressed concern about the administrative workload and pressures faced by teachers.  Our teachers work hard and have a strong sense of responsibility for their students.   As with any profession in Singapore, there is a certain intensity on the job and, occasionally, a degree of stress involved.  We are addressing this.  At the macro level, we will continue to recruit more teachers so that each officer's teaching responsibilities will be manageable. 

 

     We will also continue to ensure that, more fundamentally, our teachers have the skills and experiences they need to do their job well and to do their job confidently.   Mdm Ho asked what improvements we were making to develop our teachers.  Our teachers enjoy opportunities for professional development throughout their careers. In fact, I dare say we have one of the strongest and

Column: 2372

most comprehensive training and development opportunities for teachers anywhere in the world.  The National Institute of Education has undergone a complete revamp in the last five years and has restructured its courses to ensure they remain relevant to the needs of MOE and the schools.  NIE offers good quality teacher training that strikes the right balance of emphasis on values education, pedagogical approaches and content training.  NIE lecturers manage their classes to allow for discussion and participation, so that trainee teachers can transfer these same practices that encourage creative and critical thinking to the classroom.  NIE is constantly looking forward, identifying new challenges and seeing how it can prepare our teachers, current and future, for the new challenges.

 

     NIE is undertaking a comprehensive review of its initial teacher training programmes.  It intends to broaden the range of learning and development opportunities in these programmes. The curriculum will incorporate more experiential learning and more space for teachers to reflect on ideas, and experiment.

at NIE, MOE provides various other development options for our Education Officers.  Mdm Halimah asked about private sector attachments for our teachers.  MOE started the Teacher Work Attachment programme during the November/December holidays last year.  It is part of the broader range of options that we are providing under the Professional Development Leave Scheme.  Instead of using the Professional Development Leave solely to pursue academic development, they can also use the Professional Development Leave Scheme for industrial attachments or for

     I agree with Dr Tan Boon Wan, who spoke earlier this morning, that as we expand our post-secondary sector, and our university sector in particular, we must ensure that the quality of the education is not compromised.   As we approach our targets in enrolment, our focus has to shift.  The universities have to shift from a predominant focus on quantity to one of quality, as part of the broader reorientation we have been taking in recent years in the education system as a whole.  The universities have to go beyond producing high averages, to producing diverse talents and high peaks of excellence, as with our schools and junior colleges. For universities especially, the playing field is no longer just

Singapore or the region. They have to attain standards of excellence that place them in the first league internationally.

 

     We have certain advantages. Our universities are able to build on the high standards of Science and Mathematics education in our schools, which exceed those in most other countries. It gives our universities a starting advantage in science and engineering-related education and research especially.  We have seen increased collaboration between world-class universities and our local universities in these fields, in the form of research and academic exchange programmes, as well as the establishment of joint programmes for students. 

 

Towards Greater Autonomy and Accountability for Universities

 

      To make the next leap in quality, our universities need to be dynamic and forward-looking institutions.  They have to attract and retain first-rate faculty. They have to review their teaching and assessment methods so as to groom graduates with a willingness to think originally.  And besides producing graduates of the right quality, the universities have to play a growing role in building Singapore's research capabilities, as Dr Gan See Khem has just spoken on.  Our universities will be key players in generating the ferment and advances in research and innovation that will take Singapore up the value chain, and establish us as a leading hub in the knowledge-based world.   Meeting these two objectives - of producing thinking and enterprising graduates and developing a vibrant and self-sustaining tradition of research - will be the major challenges for our universities in the decade ahead.

 

     The university landscape itself will become more competitive, as we allow private universities in and as we restructure our publicly-funded universities.  Globally, our universities also face

Column: 2421

more competition, including more competition for the Singapore students.  Competition will provide the spur for them to achieve the quality they need in the next phase of development. 

 

     However, competition will have a positive impact only if our universities have the institutional autonomy to respond to the new opportunities and challenges. They must have both the room and the appetite to differentiate themselves, play on their respective strengths, and respond to changes in the demands of the marketplace. 

 

     Over the next few years, we will re-examine the relationship between Government and the universities to see how we can provide the universities with greater institutional autonomy in future.  It will be a broad-ranging review.  The issues we have to consider include the scope of autonomy and the universities' sourcing and use of funds, how they charge fees, how they select students, how they compete for research funds on a competitive basis, and how they remain accountable as publicly-funded universities.  These areas will build on changes already in place following a review four years ago of university governance and funding which led to NUS and NTU being given a greater degree of autonomy in various operational areas.

 

     Greater autonomy must also mean greater accountability on the part of the universities, as Dr Wang and Dr Amy Khor have rightly pointed out.  As Dr Khor also highlighted, the universities must deliver the best value-for-money from the substantial public funds given to them.  Without clear processes for accountability, increased autonomy is unlikely to yield positive results.

 

     This is why MOE initiated a Quality Assurance Framework for Universities (QAFU) to provide for continuous assessment of the quality of the

Column: 2422

institutions and their leadership.  As part of this framework, we appointed an external review panel last year, chaired by Dr Jennifer Lee. This panel will conduct an independent, external validation of each university's self-assessment once in three years.  It will report its findings and recommendations to the Minister. Amongst other things, the panel will identify and highlight the strengths and areas for improvements of the universities. The first validation exercise will be conducted in NUS in the second half of this year. 

 

     MOE will monitor the universities' follow-up on the panel's recommendations.  It is also in the interest of the universities themselves to take this external quality assurance process seriously, so as to improve quality and ensure they retain their credibility and public confidence as they move towards autonomy.

 

     NUS and NTU have also adjusted their internal governance structures to strengthen their processes of accountability internally, as they give faculties more room and more operating flexibility. Both universities have made comprehensive changes to the structure of their respective Councils, to better allow the Councils to shoulder a greater role in providing strategic directions and guiding the development of their respective universities. For example, both NUS and NTU have put in place a dedicated Audit Committee and an Establishment Committee at the Council level, to ensure proper financial practices and rigorous academic appointment processes. 

 

     Greater autonomy will also mean greater responsibilities for the university councils and leadership themselves.  We have taken great care in identifying and selecting university Council members.  We have been very fortunate to have passionate and capable Council chairmen and members serving on our three

university Councils. These are individuals who carry heavy responsibilities in their own business lives, but have been willing to give valuable time and energy to the running of the universities.

University Admission

 

     As I mentioned yesterday, the Government has accepted the recommendations of the University Admissions Committee (UAC), chaired by Prof. Chong Chi Tat, to allow greater flexibility for the universities and their faculties to decide on admission criteria for their students.  The UAC's recommendations represent the first major step in the direction of autonomy in admissions.  I thank Dr Wang Kai Yuen, Mr Zainudin Nordin, Dr Lily Neo, Mrs Fang Ai Lian and several others, including Mdm Halimah, who have supported the changes in admission requirements.

 

     The flexibility given to the universities to admit 10% of their respective intakes on independent criteria, and the introduction of faculty scores in addition to the common university scores, are important changes for both the universities and the education system as a whole.  They represent a shift from a "one-size-fits-all" measure of aptitude and suitability for university education, towards broader and more flexible measures on merit.  I spoke yesterday of the rationale for the similar enhancements that we are making in the school system. The changes in admission practices also mark, as I just mentioned, an important

Column: 2424

step in the longer term process of creating greater autonomy, greater room for universities to do what is best to develop excellence.  For NUS and NTU to go forward in a more competitive university environment locally, regionally and globally, it is essential that they be able to select the best students.

 

     Mr Iswaran is quite right that the decision-making on university admissions has to be decentralised.  This is, in fact, what the UAC's recommendations have allowed for.  He mentioned medicine.  In fact, the medical faculty is a good example of a faculty that is making the most of the extra room that is now provided for faculty decision-making in the new admission process. 

 

     The way we are moving is the way in which the best universities internationally select their students. And it would mean moving away from a single definition of merit towards more variegated definitions of merit.  It would lead to an initial uneasiness because not everyone is going to know on exactly what basis they are getting into the university, but it is a move that we have to take and which students will realise is in their best interest.

 

     Let me give you an example of why a move away from a single definition of merit towards more variegated definitions is not a move away from merit, but a move towards merit.  It is not a move that lessens the meritocratic nature of the system, but a move that reinforces the meritocratic nature of the system.  I will give you the example of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Boston, which has a very strong reputation.  Bob Brown, the Provost of MIT, was explaining their admission system to me. They get 12,000 applications each year - all very good students.  Their first step is to shortlist from 12,000 down to 6,000. So they look at school examination results, because they do not have national

Column: 2425

examinations in the States.  They look at their school test scores, they look at their advance placement tests, they look at the SAT I tests, and sometimes SAT II.  They look at all the observable grades, the sort of thing that we have been doing. That brings it down from 12,000 to 6,000.  Then they have to take it from 6,000 down to 1,500.  They do not look at the grades anymore. They look at the whole range of other achievements of a student, not just non-academic achievements, but even intellectual achievements, in other words not just climbing a mountain or canoeing.  They read carefully the testimonials of the principals. They find out what the student has done that is more than regular.  What research and special projects he has done.  Whether he shows the intellectual spark that they want in the school.

 

     It is a rigorous process, not precise but rigorous; not single-definition, but meritocratic.  That is how one university does it and there are many others that follow an essentially similar process. I asked Bob Brown why they did not look at the differentiation in SAT scores, for instance, to bring the numbers down from 6,000 to 1,000.  He gave me a simple answer.  He said that the difference between a SAT score of 1,500 and 1,600 is only two wrong answers.  That is why they do not use SAT score to bring it down from 6,000 to 1,500 students.  Because two wrong answers is not the way in which we identify the best student. I agree that as we liberalise, it will be a more complex environment for students to navigate, but it is an environment for the better.

 

     I wish to assure all Members who have spoken on this topic that meritocracy will remain a key principle for the selection of students in our publicly-funded universities.

 

      The Chinese are moving the same way incidentally.  The top Chinese

Column: 2426

universities have, in fact, earlier than us, opened up to 5% of their students being taken in on independent criteria. The Chinese have a thoroughly meritocratic system, with national examinations at all levels, transparent and meritocratic.  But they decided earlier than us that their top universities have to start taking students who are more than regular.

 

     The universities will be accountable to the Ministry in ensuring that meritocracy is preserved in their respective admission processes.  However, I would not preclude MOE initiating occasional independent audits of the universities' admission systems.

University Funding

 

     Members have raised concerns and views over the question of university fees, particularly the potential increase in university fees over the long term. This issue was discussed during the debate on the Government Budget last week.  Let me explain from the perspective of the Education budget why we have to address this issue, and not duck it. 

 

     In the US, UK and Australia, universities are having to raise tuition fees to meet rising costs and declining availability of state and federal government funding. Even after the

Column: 2429

debate recently in the UK, some of their top universities are already saying that the increase in fees, that was finally allowed for in Parliament, is not going to be sufficient for them to continue status quo with regard to which students they take in.    Oxford University has announced that it is going to take in more foreign students now, and less UK students, because it loses too much money educating each British student.

 

     Hong Kong has just cut its university budget by 10%, again because they face a tightly constrained  government budget situation.   Fortunately, we are not in dire fiscal straits in Singapore.  MOE does not expect to have its budget to be reduced by MOF over the medium or long term.  And we do not expect to cut what we spend on the universities today in absolute terms.     

 

     But the status quo formula for MOE subsidies for university education will mean that university spending will continue to increase rapidly in coming years, as more Singaporeans are admitted into our universities, and as the quality of university education goes up.  From 1998 to 2002, total expenditure on the universities grew by 41%, mainly because of larger student enrolments.  By 2010, when our university cohort participation rate reaches 25%, the university enrolment would have increased by more than 15,000 students.  This would require $350 million more in recurrent funding alone  -  not including the development cost  -   an increase of 42%,  and not $25 million as suggested by Mr Steve Chia.  We must not forget that for every one student that the university admits, the Government would have to subsidise him for three to four years, not just one year.

 

     MOE receives a budget of 4% of GDP.  Just as Mr Khaw Boon Wan says for Health, I will fight for every additional cent for Education.  But I cannot assume

Column: 2430

that the Government will have additional money to be dispensed.  The basic issue that MOE faces therefore is how to allocate a budget of 4% of GDP at a time when we are opening up university places for more students.  Do we accept a continued increase in the share of the education budget going to university education, and a corresponding cut in the share of spending elsewhere - in our schools, ITEs and polytechnics?  It is neither feasible nor desirable to allow this to happen.  Spending on these other sectors in basic, secondary and post-secondary education cannot be reduced in the coming years, as we strive for improvements in the quality of education across the entire spectrum of our student population.

 

     Our current co-funding formula is for undergraduates to pay 25% of the operating cost of their university education while the Government pays the remaining 75%.  Only 25% of recurrent cost is borne by the undergraduates.  University students enjoy a much higher dollar subsidy from Government than other students.  Last year, the average subsidy per year which a university undergraduate received was double that of a polytechnic or ITE student; 3½ times that of a secondary school student, and five times that of a primary school student.  Add to this is the fact that a university student is subsidised for more years of education, from the time he enters Primary 1, compared to students in our polytechnics and ITEs.  Take, for instance, the cost of providing students with post-secondary education from after the secondary stage.  So, for a university student, it is JC plus university education.  For an ITE student, it is two years of ITE education.  For a polytechnic student, it is three years of polytechnic education. The Government, on present subsidy rates, subsidises a university student over six years of post-secondary education, five times more than an ITE student who receives two years of an ITE subsidy.

    

Column: 2431

     We should therefore review if undergraduates should pay a higher share of the cost of university education, as Dr Gan See Khem has argued.  They are subsidised much more heavily than other students in the education system.  They also stand to benefit the most by commanding a higher salary when they join the workforce, and that remains true, even accepting Mr Gan Kim Yong's point that they add value to the economy.  But if we compare what a university student earns over his lifetime compared to what a polytechnic or ITE student earns, and if we compare what subsidies we are providing them, we have to come away with the feeling that there is some disjunct.  We have to review this.

 

     As we open our universities for more Singaporeans to go through university education, the total share of the education budget will go up, crowding out our spending on other students in the system.  MOE will therefore review the cost sharing formula in the universities, and study carefully the proportion to be borne by the undergraduates.

 

     We will also see how the universities can best distinguish between the costs of teaching and research programmes.  We should decide on a fair share of the teaching costs that should be borne by students.  In the US, for example, universities' activities in teaching and research attract different streams of funding.  Teaching is funded primarily by tuition fees and government grants.  Research costs, such as infrastructure including depreciation charges, direct and indirect costs, are recovered on a project basis from research sponsors. 

 

     Mr Gan Kim Yong suggested raising taxes to subsidise university education.  This is a MOF matter.  But I am not sure that doing so will be equitable, because not all taxpayers are graduates, and there

Column: 2432

is no reason why all taxpayers should subsidise graduates.

 

Financial Assistance

 

     MOE will ensure that no deserving student is denied a university education on grounds of financial difficulties.  Admission will be needs-blind.  If a student can get in on his merits, we will want to make sure he is not deterred from accepting the place for financial reasons.  We are well aware of the median salary in Singapore.  We are well aware of the needs of poor students, and we want to make sure that they get financial assistance in the form of bursaries and also other means.

 

     We are also aware of the needs of the middle class, and we want to ensure that the middle class does not feel squeezed out of a university education.  So, we will study all possible financial schemes to ensure that access to university education is open to all.

 

     We have to consider seriously the matter of loans.     Taking a loan to pay for an undergraduate education is a common phenomenon in countries like Australia and the US.  In the US, almost half of their full-time undergraduates take up loans to pay for part or all of university education.  We will not want loan schemes to be onerous on young graduates.  They will not be a burden.  They will not deter graduates who marry from wanting to procreate.   We can also study the "graduate tax" idea, which was mentioned by Mr Iswaran during the Budget debate, and I believe by Dr Amy Khor.  There are many variants of this internationally.  There are some schemes in Australia and the UK, for instance, which are essentially loan schemes which are operating through the tax system.  We will study all the possibilities carefully.

 

     As Dr Khor has rightly pointed out, part-time work is another way students

Column: 2433

can help pay for at least part of their education.  All three universities have established schemes for students to work in the schools or offices on campus to earn money to meet their expenses in the university.  For example, NTU has a scheme where students are recruited as student assistants, and paid to carry out routine duties, while SMU has a work-study grant scheme.  But we can do more in this area.  Part-time work is far more common amongst university students abroad, both within and outside the campuses, than in Singapore.  In fact, I myself earned a handsome stipend washing dishes in a restaurant when I was doing my undergraduate education in the UK.

 

Endowments and Donations

 

     Philanthropy is another source of income for the universities.  In the US, donations from individuals and private organisations have helped many universities build up substantial endowments as a major funding source.  Dr Khor pointed out that it would be more difficult to raise funds here, and Dr Gan See Khem also addressed this issue.  There is a point there.  The culture of philanthropy in Singapore is not as developed as in the US.  But it is not negligible.  Just last month, NTU received a benefaction of $5 million from Mr Ng Bok Eng.  Our universities are seeking to develop this tradition.  They will have to do more to engage private donors, as Dr Gan See Khem has pointed out, especially the alumni who have benefited from their university education and have become successful in life.  The Government,

on its part, is committed to helping our local universities build up their endowment funds, by matching their donations which universities received.

"Protection" versus Flexibility

 

      Of all the manpower issues that surfaced in the last few months and the last two years that my cohort of Members of Parliament came into this House and were faced with, the one that had the most significant impact on how we protect jobs and livelihoods for Singaporeans was a fundamentally important question.  And during those turbulent times, some form of protection or other had been asked in a variety of ways, whether it was in legislation to promote hiring or making it more difficult to retrench Singaporeans, special rights for anti-discrimination of the elderly, minorities, parents, part-time workers - like some of you have mentioned today.  Others have asked for more predictable and assured terms in wages and benefits or working hours, so that workers' remuneration was better protected.   And, of course, we have the perennial requests, as we have this afternoon, to restrict access to foreign workers, so that Singaporeans are favoured for these jobs. 

 

     Members of the House, we are not alone in asking for these seeming forms of protection.  Indeed, all over the world, this is an issue which countries are grappling with.  US presidential candidate, Senator John Kerry, wants to get tough on companies which outsource operations outside the US.  The Dutch government recently decided that local employers must make sure that no Dutch person is available for a job before attempting to recruit workers from the 10 new Central and Eastern European countries joining the

Column: 2502

European Union.  In the meantime, of course, businesses are concerned with competition and costs.  They are deciding if they can survive and stay, or uproot, or change industries.
