     How can we help Singaporeans get jobs and earn a livelihood? Mr Low Thia Khiang said this is the Government's responsibility, otherwise, we have no moral right to start the stayers-and-quitters debate.  I agree fully with him.  I accept that it is the Government's responsibility to do this.  And if by introducing laws that make it harder for companies to right-size, keep wages up, and keep foreign workers out can ensure jobs for Singaporeans, then the solutions would be obvious and, in fact, easier to do.  We pass the laws, Singaporeans are pleased, and they will find their jobs secure and livelihoods preserved.  But will they?  Other countries have gone that way and have not succeeded.  Indeed, it has worsened unemployment.

 

     I want to show Members some charts, and I have asked the Clerk to circulate them. This is the first chart that I will show.  On average, over the period 1997-2001 - and I have particularly chosen the last few years which were difficult years for us - continental European countries, such as France, Germany and Spain, had employment rates of above 10%.  I would like to remind Members that they did not suffer SARS, they did not have the Bali bombing, and there was no Asian financial crisis that afflicted them. 

 

     This was compared to 4.5% for the US, 5.9% for the UK and 3.0% for Singapore.  Why this sharp difference?  One answer is the extent to which these countries regulate their labour market.  The Anglo-Saxon model of the UK and US, in particular, believes in flexible labour markets.  They regulate, as all countries do, on safety and health matters.  But

Column: 2503

they allow firms flexibility in right sizing, in hiring and firing.  Compared to other countries, they are not overly generous in their statutory leave and benefit provisions, or have overly restrictive working hours. 

 

     These flexibilities allow US companies to respond quickly to external changes, to seize new business opportunities and to move out of unprofitable areas.  A Business Week article, contributed by a US professor of economics, Russell Roberts, highlights and examines what happened to the manufacturing sector in the US, because US manufacturing only accounts for about 12% of jobs. They have had to go through wrenching times as well.  He said that the sector had to shed jobs due to productivity gains or plant relocations.  But it freed up workers so that they could move into new industries and new jobs, eg, in telecommunications, software and biotech.  New goods and services became available to consumers.  The improvements in productivity kept wages, raised the standard of living for all.  So despite the churn with retrenchments and re-hiring, unemployment rates, wages and standard of living held and were better than others with rigid labour markets. In other words, this market flexibility which at face value appears harsh, in fact accords more job and income security not only for the more employable but indeed for all.

 

      Some Members have asked about the impact of outsourcing.  McKinsey, the global consultancy firm, estimates that every US$1 spent in the US on offshore services generates a total benefit of about US$1.45.  What about jobs?  Again, the report says that even if two million jobs are outsourced, moved out of the US, this frees up 22 million jobs that the US Bureau of Labour Statistics estimates will be created over the next 10 years.  How

Column: 2504

certain these forecasts are, only time will tell.  The academics are convinced, including the Presidential advisor, that these spurts of technological discontinuity we see now have had the same effect in the past, and the outcome will be repeated.  But I presume, in an election year in the US, workers are doubtful and, even if politicians believe the academics, they would be reluctant to say so.

 

      But what about the supposedly more secure environments in continental European countries which seek to protect workers' jobs with more rigid labour, wage and other benefits?  It is spurious protection, as their companies are less able to change in an increasing volatile environment.  The result?  Job growth slows, and descriptions like "Eurosclerosis" or "arthritic economies" emerge.  For years, economists and business leaders have lamented that Germany's restrictive labour laws did little to stem their high unemployment rate of 10%.  On average, unemployed people in Germany remain out of work longer than in other countries.  The process of job placement is lengthy and complicated. And the unemployment and social security benefits in the systems are expensive solutions that literally tax the system.  So, Chancellor Schroder plans to implement a series of reforms to modernise the labour market and to create jobs.  All these reforms are part of the Agenda 2010 package of social and economic reforms to boost the economy. They plan to limit the jobless benefits to one year instead of 32 months to free up regulations to enable firms to hire and fire temporary or permanent workers. 

 

      Denmark too liberalised the labour market in the early 1990s.  They experienced an employment boom and improved their unemployment rate to 6%.  Denmark's economy has averaged 2.6% annual growth since 1994.  They cut entitlements, including social security transfers, and raised indirect taxes.  That

Column: 2505

gave them the ability to shift resources into higher education and research and development.   Denmark is the third largest exporter of pharmaceuticals per capita and among the world leaders in biotechnology patents.           

      Even in USA, this simple fact that more protection does not necessarily afford more job security is being borne out.  The California State under the Democrat Governor enacted or expanded half-a-dozen laws dealing with labour market regulations.  Especially onerous on businesses were the three laws on: (1) paid six weeks family-leave act; (2) a mandated increase in workers' compensation amounting to more than twice the US national average; and, (3) increasing overtime pay which was mandated for anyone who works more than eight hours a day. This makes it expensive for businesses that operated four 10-hour days or those call centres which operated 12-hour days. 

 

      Companies in California responded and since 2001, the state has lost about 300,000 jobs.  Even in developing economies, the leaders have realised the same point. In the post-Raj era of India, it was very difficult to hire and fire.   In fact, it needed a bureaucracy to administer all those rigidities that were there by fear.  But in the early 90s, the Finance Minister, Manmohan Singh began the process of liberalising the system and allowing businesses to respond without the onerous stipulations imposed by government.

 

      As a result of that enlightened move, all countries including Singapore are experiencing this extraordinary rise in the productivity growth of Indian industries. Yes, India was lucky and took advantage of the IT boom and bust.  But we should recognise that while India had the educated masses, previously rigid conditions stifled their productivity.

      I have gone into some length on this issue because this is a fundamental point which under-girds the principles upon which we craft our labour policies. All these examples show that excess rigidity, instead of protecting workers, leads to economic stagnation and loss of jobs.

In the area of outsourcing, some Members have asked what the impact is.  We could lose some jobs overseas because others can do it better or at a lower cost.  This is a global phenomenon and there is not much that we can do about it.  But we can also benefit from offshoring.  In fact, our manufacturing sector first started as MNCs offshored production, design, support and headquarter functions.  We were among the first beneficiaries of outsourcing. As more higher valued and higher technology content manufacturing investments came, labour intensive manufacturing then shifted to cheaper locations.  That freed up local manpower to go into the growing services sector.  If we had blocked that then in 1970s and 1980s, the consequences today would have been devastating, as more workers would lose their jobs. 

 

Meeting competition head-on:  the way to growth and jobs

 

      How then do we protect ourselves and jobs for Singaporeans?  I come back to the key question - not by shutting out competition, but meeting it head-on.  MTI Minister, BG George Yeo mentioned this in his speech.  Let me reiterate.  We can compete on four aspects: 

 

     Firstly, value plus.  We can never be cheap but we can moderate the costs to do business here by keeping statutory burdens low and adding value - whether it is CPF, taxes, utilities, land and wages.  We need to give companies the flexibility to respond and the wage restructuring efforts that we have been talking about recently should be seen in this light. 

 

Column: 2507

      Thirdly, a best workforce - an effective and efficient labour market, highly trained local workers and, I would say, access to foreign workers - not deprivation - is a critical element both to allow diversity in skill base and help businesses average their costs.

      With this strategy, we have created growth in the past and we will continue to do so. Singaporeans need not lose heart.

Changed Job Landscape

and that is, to provide only jobs of the type that are appealing and attractive to Singaporeans. No government can promise this. What types of jobs exist in our economy cannot be mandated by the wishes and wants of Singaporeans or the Government, but by market place realities.  As Members have understood and expressed, the job market has fundamentally changed.  And even though we have more jobs than Singaporeans, groups of workers are at risk due to structural unemployment.  I will talk about this later.

 

5.00 pm

 

     But even despite growth, unemployment will hover at around 3% to 4%.  There is a mismatch of job seekers against the jobs that exist in expectations and skills.  If this is not addressed, unemployment will go higher. The Government understands this.  It is committed to help Singaporeans stay employable. This is a challenge that involves us all. We will work with NTUC, our social partners, the Mayors of CDCs and Members of this House to overcome this challenge.

A service economy

 

     As I have said, the majority of jobs will be in the services sector.  Manufacturing jobs have dropped from about 30% to about 20% now.  Like many developed countries, two-thirds of our jobs are in the services sector. DPM Lee showed this Chart during the Budget debate.  It bears reiterating.  In the last 10 years, 500,000 jobs were created.  The net number of jobs in manufacturing was nil.  It was almost predominantly in the services sector.

 

     The services sector will be the main driver of employment, but that does mean

Column: 2512

that we do not need manufacturing, because they generate a lot of indirect impact.  Jobs will increase in areas such as hotels and restaurants, in education, healthcare, transport and logistics, communications and media.  There are jobs available at all levels.  Over the past few years, when you look at our figures, some of the fastest growing occupations in the sector were university lecturers and other education professionals, management consultants and financial analysts on the one hand, and bell boys, cleaners, and security services on the other.

 

Service skills required

 

     Members have asked what this new job landscape means for workers. Will they have the right skills? The shift from manufacturing to services will have implications on our competitive edge. Very few doubt the technical capability of our workforce. Our workers have consistently ranked well globally in terms of productivity and efficiency, according to the BERI reports. They are efficient, diligent and rational to problem solving, and these have served us well. But my point is, in terms of employment, when we are a service driven economy, we will do less well.  What is the reason?  One of the reasons is that unlike manufacturing where your supply chain is your production line, your products move past you.

 

     In the services sector, you have to get used to talking to your production line, because the quality of service lies primarily with the person delivering it, as one interacts with the customers and responds to their needs, be it in the retail, finance, consultancy or healthcare sectors. A large component of value-add is from intangibles, such as service edge, performance, ideas and concepts, which is why I think our changes in the education system are correct.  This is for pre-employment training.

If I can give a simple example, an engineer who is a CEO in the financial industry is considered to be in the services sector.    "Service skills" are best seen as an additional layer on top of technical skills.          

 

     Our challenge, therefore, is to maintain the premium for our Singapore workforce by adding skills and mindsets to achieve a thriving services sector. Singapore workers will have to provide customised solutions, handle simultaneous and varied requests. There will be less routine work, and characteristics such as inter-personal relationship, EQ, rapport-building and mentoring will be given emphasis.    And this is part of the problem with our HR management systems and employers.  Because employers, at the same time, will have to find new ways of measuring workers' productivity given the significant intangibles in the services sector.

These were questions asked during the Economic Review Committee, and I will take some time later to explain what our strategy is.

     The fourth aspect of the National Skills Framework is that we need to move from paper qualifications to directly usable skills, and for workers to acquire those skills in a shorter time.  I do not think it makes sense to tell them, "You do not have the educational qualifications, you will have to take a 2-year part-time course.  I will set up the time for you".  Two years is a very long time.  One such programme we are piloting is called Functional Literacy for Our Workers (FLOW) - I have a specific department in my Ministry that deals with creative acronyms.  Before the development of FLOW by WDA, the lowest standard of literacy was Basic Education for Skills Training (BEST).  BEST Module 1 was pegged at Primary 3 - very sensible - that was the lowest module.  But, even there, you exclude a large group of workers whose literacy level was too low even to cope with BEST Module 1.  What are you going to do?  So under FLOW, we say, let us customise the contents so that it is directly relevant to the work place context.  This is my understanding of it, not my staff.  They can disclaim responsibility for me.  I call it the "SIA girl" approach.  You need to teach the SIA stewardess contextualised literacy, "How are you, Sir?  Can I help you?"  And, of course, as the joke goes, "Study lor, cannot meh".  We need to teach the person contextualised skills for the work.  By the end of the course, workers should be able to communicate effectively in their job in simple English.  It is a good idea, but will it work?
